title: Kenya: Be Ready to Pay Higher Taxes, Kenyans Told
text:
Kenya: Cash Reward Offered for Reporting Cases of Guinea Worm Disease 
"We will either have to raise the taxes, borrow to raise the required amount, or come up with a supplementary budget, which will affect development spending," he said. 
Thugge said raising taxes will scare away investors, at a time when the government requires increased foreign direct and local investments to bridge the financial gap. 
Kenya has a budget deficit of Sh500 billion. 
Meanwhile, government officials met yesterday at the National Treasury to find cash to pay the teachers. 
On Monday, the Supreme Court said it had no jurisdiction to adjudicate over the 50-60 per cent salary increment awarded earlier by a court. 
This has left the government with no option but to look for ways to pay teachers by September 3. 
On September 22 the Court of Appeal will review how the Teachers Service Commission has complied with the orders. Kenya
